original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares pick up on a 72 week high on DDO
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka stocks closed up on Wednesday after domestic bond restructuring assurances and fears on investing in the banking sector diminished, sparking interest in the banking counters due to undervalued share price, an analyst said.

The All Share Price Index (ASPI) edged up 1.11 percent or 131.22 points to 10,927.07, this is the highest the market has been since March 04, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was up 0.87 percent or 127.62 points to 3,190.28, according to exchange provisional data.

“There is continued interest in the banking sector, because the shares have been down for so long it is undervalued and it still is, which is why the sector is gaining along with the market,” an analyst said.

The market has continuously being seeing gains on domestic debt optimization (DDO) since July 04 and due to the prior fears on DDO, investors held back on investing in the banking sector which resulted in the market to moving down.
Sri Lanka’s announced domestic debt restructuring plan has avoided adding to the “fragility” of the banking system, World bank Country Director Faris Hadad-Zervos said.
“The trick is to do it in a way that does not impact the financial sector and does not cause fragility in the financial sector,” Hadad-Zervos told a forum organized by Sri Lanka’s Press Club.
Sri Lanka kept banks, which have already been hit by bad loans and mark-to-market losses out of re-structuring plan.
Hadad-Zervos said initial analysis seems to indicate that the debt restricting is done in a sustainable way but without further impacting the banking sector.
Sri Lanka’s cabinet of ministers had approved changes to the country’s income tax law applicable to superannuation funds facilitate domestic debt restructuring, Minister Bandula Gunawardana said.
Sri Lanka authorities have said pension and provident funds that do not agree to extend maturities of their Treasury bonds will be taxed at 30 percent instead of the current 14 percent.

The market generated a turnover of 4.5 billion rupees, majority of the revenue had come from the banking sector brining in 1.5 billion rupees, while the diversified financials sector brought in 996 million rupees and the capital sector brought in 428 million rupees.
The banking sector is picking up on domestic debt optimization assurances, while investors are seeking alternative investments bringing up the market on green, an analyst said.
The overall market is moving up on domestic debt optimization assurances, picking up several stock counters in the market such as the capital sector.
Top gainers were Sampath Bank, DFCC Bank and Commercial Bank. (Colombo/July19/2023)
